abstract.p: Christine Kenneally reviews book The Lying Stones of Marrakech: Penultimate Reflections in Natural History by Stephen Jay Gould (S)

block.p: In his ninth essay collection, Stephen Jay Gould treks through the physical and natural sciences, strolls through centuries of thought, writes lively biographies and revisits themes like ''our generation's fundamental confusion of celebrity with stature.'' Gould, whose previous books include ''The Mismeasure of Man,'' is a professor of geology and the Alexander Agassiz professor of zoology at Harvard. He detests oversimplification, yet he has a talent for breathing life into cliche and applying aphorisms in unexpected places. He explains how the fortunes of the 17th-century scholar Francesco Stelluti might have differed had he only remembered the principle embodied in the jokes that begin, ''I've got some good news and some bad news.'' Gould also dabbles in semiotics, speculating about the significance attributed to the number four, and he emotes: tears still spring to his eyes when he reads the final words of the explorer Robert Falcon Scott, and he begins a footnote with ''Don't get me started.'' His passionate commitment to precision and his sensitivity to ''the little wriggles of a million 'might have beens,' ''make ''The Lying Stones of Marrakech'' not just accessible but stimulating as well.
